pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:0.5: Venerables, these two undetermined rules come up for recitation.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.2: At that time Venerable Udāyī was associating with and visiting a number of families in Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.3: On one occasion one of the families that supported him gave their daughter in marriage to the son of another family.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.4: Soon afterwards Venerable Udāyī robed up in the morning, took his bowl and robe, and went to the first of those families. When he arrived, he asked
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.7: that she had been given to another family.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.9: He then went there and again asked
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.13: He went up to that girl, and the two of them sat down alone on a private and concealed seat suitable for action. When they were able, they chatted; otherwise he gave her a teaching.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.14: At that time Visākhā Migāramātā had many healthy children and grandchildren. As a consequence, she was considered auspicious.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.15: At sacrifices, ceremonies, and celebrations people would feed Visākhā first.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.16: Just then she had been invited to that family that supported Udāyī.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.17: When she arrived, she saw him sitting alone with that girl,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.19: “Venerable, it’s not appropriate for you to sit alone with a woman on a private and concealed seat suitable for action.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.20: You may not be aiming at that act, but it’s hard to convince people with little confidence.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.22: After leaving, Visākhā told the monks what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.23: The monks of few desires complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.24: “How could Venerable Udāyī sit alone with a woman on a private and concealed seat suitable for action?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.25: After rebuking Udāyī in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Udāyī:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.26: “Is it true, Udāyī, that you did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.29: “Foolish man, how could you do this?
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.31: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.32.1: ‘If a monk sits alone with a woman on a private and concealed seat suitable for action, and a trustworthy female lay follower sees him
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.33: and accuses him of an offense entailing expulsion, an offense entailing suspension, or an offense entailing confession,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.34: then, if he admits to the sitting, he is to be dealt with according to one of these three
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:1.35: or according to what that trustworthy female lay follower has said.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:2.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:2.1.6: a human female, not a female spirit, not a female ghost, not a female animal; even a girl born that very day, let alone an older one.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:2.1.10: just the monk and the woman.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:2.1.12: there is private to the eye and there is private to the ear.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:2.1.14: one is unable to see them winking, raising an eyebrow, or nodding.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:2.1.16: one is unable to hear ordinary speech.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:2.1.18: it is concealed by a wall, a screen, a door, a cloth screen, a tree, a pillar, a grain container, or anything else.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:2.1.20: one is able to have sexual intercourse.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:2.1.22: the monk sits down or lies down next to the seated woman.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:2.1.23: The woman sits down or lies down next to the seated monk.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:2.1.24: Both are seated or both are lying down.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:2.1.26: she has attained the fruit, she has broken through, she has understood the Teaching.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:2.1.28: she has gone for refuge to the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Sangha.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:3.1: If he admits to going, and he admits to sitting, and he admits to an offense, he is to be dealt with for the offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:3.2: If he admits to going, but he does not admit to sitting, yet he admits to an offense, he is to be dealt with for the offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:3.3: If he admits to going, and he admits to sitting, but he does not admit to an offense, he is to be dealt with for the sitting.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ay1:3.4: If he admits to going, but he does not admit to sitting, nor does he admit to an offense, he is not to be dealt with.
